prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Figure 1 shows the ALMA 230 GHz image of HD 61005 with a beam size of 1.06x0.69 arcsec and a rms sensitivity of 0.05 mJy/beam (project 2012.1.00437.S, PI: David Rodriguez). The total flux density of ~4 mJy is much less that suggested by the prior SMA imaging (7 mJy). The ALMA peak flux density was 1.1 mJy/beam. We scale from the image and simulation of HD 32297 to estimate a peak signal for our configuration of 0.3 mJy/beam. We propose to integrate to a signal-to-noise on this flux density of 15, or 0.019 mJy/beam. This is more than a factor of 2 better than the previous imaging.
We use the default single continuum spectral setup. Cycle 1 observations did not detect CO in the disk.

The ALMA image in Figure 1 (beam 1.06 x 0.69 arcsec) shows that the disk has a radius of approximtely 1.5 arcsec, which is larger than the size of the parent planetesimal ring inferred in scattered light observations (0.8 arcsec). Something complex is going on in the disk because the SED didn't correctly predict the total flux seen in imaging, and there appear to be multiple belts of dust with temperatures of ~60 K and ~25K. The ALMA image also shows that the NE side of the disk is brighter than the SW side.
We request a spatial resolution of 0.4 arcsec to be able to 1) resolve multiple beams along the disk midplane out to 0.8 arcsec and between 0.8 and 1.5 arcsec to unambiguously detect the parent planetesimal locations, 2) image the "wings" of swept-back dust if they contain large grains, and 3) detect the location of the NE/SW asymmetry. Since the surface brightness of the wings falls off in scattered light as a steep function of distance from the ring (distance to the power of 3 to 4), teasing apart the structure at the junction between the disk and wings requires high to separate the disk midplane and extended structure. The requested resolution is about 2x better than the previous observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging of HD 32297
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum imaging of disk plus free CO

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This disk has in integrated 1.3 mm flux density of 3.1 +/- 0.74 mJy. We took the 1.3 mm flux density and distributed it in a disk midplane whose structure is inferred from the scattered light observations of Currie et al. 2012. This structure is consistent with the 1.3 mm image and the SED in Donaldson et al. 2013, which fits the Spitzer mid-infrared, Herschel, and CARMA flux densities with a combination of two blackbodies, representing two dust belts, with temperatures of 240 and 83 K. The cold component is necessary to match the 500 micron and 1.3 mm photometry. See left panel of Figure 2. We then added extended emission that follows the surface brightness of the scattered light observed with HST, but kept the total flux density constant (right panel of Figure 2). These simulations were done for configuration C36-4. The simulations are for S/N=40 in the case where all the flux is concentrated in the midplane; this corresponds to the requested 0.019 mJy/beam. Should the submm grains be extended, this same sensitivity/beam corresponds to S/N=10 on extended emission. The simulations show that this sensitivity is sufficient to distinguish whether the submm grains lie only the disk midplane or share the same extended distribution as the very small grains seen in scattered light.
We have no particular expectation that there is any CO in the disk. The Baseband-1 observations of CO v=0 2-1 will have a sensitivity of 1.8 mJy (the integration time is set by the continuum, so this is just what we get for "free", and we use this as the "expected" peak line flux density entered in the Field Setup in the OT). This is a factor of 4.5 times more sensitive than the CO upper limit (7.3 mJy) in Maness et al. 2008. We expect the Keplerian rotational line width to be 3 km/s at the belt radius, so the lowest spectral resolution of 1.3 km/s is fine for line detection. The detectable gas mass of CO is so small that it's equivalent to the CO in a few thousand Hale-Bopp-like comets. We assume no H2 is present, because debris disks have only secondary gas. The detectable CO mass is, of course, much much less than the 0.1 Earth masses estimated dust mass from Donaldson et al. 2013.

We modify the default single continuum spectral setup. We keep the total bandwidth (2000 MHz in each baseband, 7.5 GHz total), but we move one of the basebands to cover the CO (2-1) line. There is no loss of sensitivity in the continuum by doing this, but we gain the ability to look for molecular gas.

Figure 1 of our science justification shows that the 1.3 mm image from CARMA only marginally resolves the disk with a beam size of 0.9 arcsec and sensitivity of 0.44 mJy/beam. We request 0.5 arcsec spatial resolution to 1) resolve the disk across several beams (see Table 1: belt radius = 1.7 arcsec and kink radius = 2.3 arcsec), 2) probe the crucial transition to the wing features (1 - 2 arcsec) while still retaining short baselines that will pick up extended flux features. In the scattered light, he surface brightness of the swept-back wings fall off as a steep function of distance from the ring (distance to the power of 3 to 4), so we do not expect significant flux beyond 5 arcsec.

SMA measured a total disk flux density of 2.6 (+0.5, -0.8) mJy. This agrees well with extrapolations of the SED to 1.3 mm that predicted 1.6 - 3.2 mJy. We scale from the image and simulation of HD 32297 to estimate a peak signal of 0.47 mJy/beam. We need enough sensitivity to distinguish any "wings" from the main disk. We therefore propose to integrate to a noise that is 5% of the peak, or 0.024 mJy/beam.

We modify the default single continuum spectral setup. We keep the total bandwidth (2000 MHz in each baseband, 7.5 GHz total), but we move one of the basebands to cover the CO (2-1) line. There is no loss of sensitivity in the continuum by doing this, but we gain the ability to look for molecular gas.
We have no particular expectation for any CO in the disk. There is an upper limit on CO(3-1) of 1.35 Jy km/s (Moor et al. 2011). For our observations, we calculate the sensitivity of Baseband-1 observations of CO v=0 2-1 with 1.3 km/s resolution in the integration time set by the continuum imaging requirements (26 min) and find that we will get 2.1 mJy per channel for "free." For purposes of the OT requirement to enter an "expected" peak line flux density, we use this sensitivity. We expect that a CO line would have a Keplerian rotational line width of 12 km/s at the belt radius of 54 AU, so the lowest spectral resolution of 1.3 km/s is more than adequate for line detection.

We request 0.5 arcsec spatial resolution to satisfy three requirements: 1) the ability to resolve multiple beams along the disk midplane to unambiguously identify the parent planetesimal locations, 2) the ability to image extended "wings" of dust if they exist, i.e. to extract low surface brightness features that vary across the scale of the disk, and 3) the ability to separate these two populations of dust, if both exist. A resolution of 0.5 arcsec will resolve the disk across several beams (Table 1: belt radius = 1.''2 and "kink" radius = 2''). It is more than 4 times better than the resolution of prior SMA imaging (shown in Figure 1, beam size 3'' x 2.''1).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose observations of a coherent sample of three edge-on disks that have all been spatially resolved at submm wavelengths and have asymmetric structures observed in scattered light. These disks share two common properties. The first is a well-defined ring of planetesimals, and the second is wings of diffuse dust, which probably come from dynamical interaction either within the disk or between the disk and interstellar medium. Our proposed observations will perform three critical functions: first, unambiguously identify the stable planetesimal belts in three edge-on disks by tracing the location of large (mm-sized) grains out to large radii and determine if these belts are circular or eccentric and therefore perturbed; second, unambiguously determine if non-planetary interaction in the form of interstellar medium ablation is occuring by looking for large grains out of the midplane, and third, measure the grain emission in the same regions as scattered light is observed thereby providing grain albedos.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Terrestrial Magnetism, Carnegie Institution of Washington
